page.title: 17COAL REPLACES PEAT
page.content: The reasons for the decline, were the opening of the new collieries whose coal was more efficient for burning than peat, the opening of the Stainforth and Keadley canal, which partly destroyed the boating dykes and meant payment of dues on the overland carriage of peat to the River Don. Finally the enclosure act, although preserving the peat on Thorne Waste, accelerated moorland reclamation and peat working waned. The use of peat as a fuel also declined, but the trade revived in the 1880's as the peat was used as animal litter, especially as bedding for horses. In 1899, 120 Dutchmen were employed on Thorne Waste working for the Griendtsreen company who had the peat trade on Thorne Waste. The Peat Moors Litter Company took over from Grievst.
